questions.question: “Differential bending” is a phenomenon that appears when the compressed panels of a wing are buckled, so that their bending stiffness contribution is different from that of the panels that remain stable.
You can neglect shear deformability for beams if the number EI/(l^2 EA) is large.
You need to use Hermitian shape functions for the displacement field when building a Timoshenko beam finite element.
σzz = E εzz is:
choices: wrong
correct for plates
correct for a state of axial stress
correct for a state of plane stress
correct for a state of plane strain
none of the above
questions.answer: correct for a state of axial stress

questions.question: The shear flux in a thin wing panel is equal to:
choices: the average shear stress divided by the panel thickness
the average shear stress multiplied by the panel thickness
the average shear stress
the derivative with respect to the chord direction of the axial stress in the panel
none of the above
questions.answer: the average shear stress multiplied by the panel thickness

questions.question: The shear stress transmitted by a glued connection is:
choices: higher at the extremities
lower at the extremities
constant
described by a sin function
described by a cos function
described by a cubic polynomial function
none of the above

questions.question: The axial stress of beam transmitting a constant bending moment Mx does not depend on the material elastic modulus E.
The Timoshenko model is used to compute the critical buckling stress of a simply supported compressed plate.
Hermitian shape functions are C2 (continuous, and with continuous first and second derivatives).
“Crippling” is:
choices: a failure mode of thin-walled compressed beam
a failure mode of compact compressed beam
a failure mode affecting the fuselage of Boeing 737 MAX
a failure mode of railways
a special design technique preventing the buckling of beams
none of the above
questions.answer: a failure mode of thin-walled compressed beam

questions.question: Assume that the solution of a given three dimensional elastic problem has a finite H10 norm; an approximated solution, obtained with quadratic finite elements with average dimension h:
choices: has quadratic convergence of the stress with respect to h
has cubic convergence of the stress with respect to h
has linear convergence of the displacements with respect to h
has quadratic convergence of the displacements with respect to h
none of the above
questions.answer: has quadratic convergence of the stress with respect to h

questions.question: A structure is modeled using finite elements. It is unconstrained and subjected to a set of loads in self-equilibrium. The solution of the linear static problem:
choices: is stress-free
can be computed, up to a rigid body motion, after constraining the structure isostatically
can be computed only if the loads are concentrated
can be computed, up to a rigid body motion, only if the loads are distributed
is defined up to a rigid body motion; thus, not being unique, it is not possible to compute the stress and strain fields
none of the above

questions.question: The internal forces in a statically determined beam structure depend on the material elastic properties.
The Timoshenko beam model does not account for transverse shear deformation.
The position of the shear center of a thin-walled beam depends on the loading conditions.
The shear flows acting on a rib are:
choices: the flows equivalent to the load introduced by the rib
the flows equivalent to the load applied to the whole structure
the flows computed from the torsional equivalence equation
the flows computed by resorting to the bending equations
the flows equilibrating the load introduced by the rib
none of the above
questions.answer: the flows equilibrating the load introduced by the rib

questions.question: The Principle of Virtual Work:
choices: is used to impose the equilibrium
is used to impose the equilibrium and the compatibility
is used to impose the compatibility
none of the above
questions.answer: is used to impose the equilibrium

questions.question: A structure is modeled using finite elements. It is unconstrained and subjected to a set of loads in self-equilibrium. The solution of the linear static problem:
choices: is stress-free
can be obtained, up to a rigid body motion, after constraining the structure isostatically
can be obtained only if the loads are concentrated
can be obtained, up to a rigid body motion, only if the loads are distributed
is defined up to a rigid body motion; thus, not being unique, the stress and displacement fields can never be computed
none of the above
questions.answer: can be obtained, up to a rigid body motion, after constraining the structure isostatically

questions.question: Any structure with one dimension much larger than the other two can likely be modeled as a beam.
According to the Timoshenko beam model, the transverse shear stresses are linear on the cross section.
The position of the shear center of a closed-cell section can be evaluated using the shear flow equations and the equivalence to internal moment.
A system of slender beams can be modeled by beams finite elements:
choices: never
if the structure can sustain the loads through an internal axial load path
only if shear deformability is not negligible
always
none of the above

questions.question: An Euler-Bernoulli cantilever beam with uniform stiffness is clamped at one extremity and loaded with a concentrated force at the tip. The solution obtained using a displacement-based method based on polynomial functions with two unknown coefficients is:
choices: exact
an approximation of the exact solution with errors below 10%
an approximation of the exact solution with errors depending on the problem data
none of the above

questions.question: The PCVW allows to:
choices: find the compatible solution among the equilibrated ones
find the equilibrated solution among the compatible ones
find the compatible and equilibrated solutions among all the possible independent stress and displacement fields
none of the above
questions.answer: find the compatible solution among the equilibrated ones

questions.question: Whenever a slender structure works in plane strain the axial deformation is null.
The critical buckling force for a simply supported compressed beam is inversely proportional to its slenderness (∝ 1/λ).
The relation σzz = E εzz is correct only for a state of plane stress.
A “simply supported” plate has:
choices: transverse displacement and bending rotation prevented on one of its boundary sides
transverse displacement and bending rotation prevented on all of its boundary sides
transverse displacement prevented on two opposite boundary sides, bending rotation left free
transverse displacement prevented on all of its boundary sides, bending rotation left free
transverse displacement and bending rotation prevented on two opposite boundary sides, transverse displacement prevented and bending rotation left free on the other two
none of the above
questions.answer: transverse displacement prevented on all of its boundary sides, bending rotation left free

questions.question: When a torsional moment is applied to a thin-walled beam, without any other load:
choices: the shear flows are null
the torsion is null
the torsion is different from zero, but only if the cross-section is free to warp
the torsion is different from zero
the torsion is different from zero only if the transverse shear deformability is not negligible
the beam is able to withstand the torsional moment only if it is slender enough
none of the above
questions.answer: the torsion is different from zero

questions.question: Thin plates typically work in plane strain conditions.
The stress field predicted by a FE solution is continuous.
The cross section of a beam subject to shear has an out-of-plane warping.
A riveted connection between two panels loaded in-plane cannot fail because of:
choices: shear stress in the panels
shear stress in the rivet
axial stress in the rivet
bearing stress in the rivet
axial stress in the panels
none of the above

questions.question: Shear deformability is important for:
choices: slender compact cross-section beams
thin-walled beams
thin panels
any kind of beam
any kind of panel
none of the above

questions.question: The axial stiffness for a thin-walled beam:
choices: is null
is generally larger with respect to a corresponding compact section
is generally smaller with respect to a corresponding compact section
is equal to that of a corresponding compact section
can be neglected
none of the above
questions.answer: is equal to that of a corresponding compact section

questions.question: The assumption of plane strain implies that a component of stress is null.
The essential boundary conditions are satisfied in a weak sense by the Principle of Virtual Work.
According to the semi-monocoque model, the axial stress σzz in the panels can be computed from the axial derivative of the shear stress.
The shear stress transmitted by a glued connection is:
choices: higher at the extremities
lower at the extremities
constant
described by a sin function
described by a cos function
described by a quadratic polynomial function
none of the above

questions.question: The bearing stress is related to:
choices: glued connections
riveted connections
the average shear stress in a semi-monocoque cross-section subject to constant torsional moment
the through-the-thickness shear stress in a Timoshenko shell model
the through-the-thickness shear stress in a Mindlin shell model
none of the above
